Expectation1: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation1: A critical call reports a multi-vehicle collision on a highway outside the city.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I was standing in the crowded polling station, my ID clutched in one hand, when the election official’s voice cut through the chatter: “Voters with last names A through M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name started with B. The new line was barely moving, but the official’s eyes met mine, expecting me to comply. I hesitated, glancing at my watch. My shift as an ambulance driver had just ended, but my radio was still clipped to my belt. Suddenly, it crackled to life: “All units, multi-vehicle collision, Highway 17, critical injuries reported.” My heart pounded. I knew every second counted in an emergency, and I was trained to respond without delay. But here, as a voter, I was expected to follow the official’s instructions, to wait my turn, to respect the process. The weight of both roles pressed down on me—one demanding immediate action, the other requiring patience and order. I stood frozen, torn between the urgent call to save lives and the civic duty to follow the rules, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
